trans-unit.source: Strongly Typed Delegates
trans-unit.target: Strongly Typed Delegates

trans-unit.source: Previous
trans-unit.target: Previous

trans-unit.source: In the previous article, you saw that you create specific delegate types using the `delegate` keyword.
trans-unit.target: In the previous article, you saw that you create specific delegate types using the `delegate` keyword.

trans-unit.source: The abstract Delegate class provide the infrastructure for loose coupling and invocation.
trans-unit.target: The abstract Delegate class provide the infrastructure for loose coupling and invocation.

trans-unit.source: Concrete Delegate types become much more useful by embracing and enforcing type safety for the methods that are added to the invocation list for a delegate object.
trans-unit.target: Concrete Delegate types become much more useful by embracing and enforcing type safety for the methods that are added to the invocation list for a delegate object.

trans-unit.source: When you use the `delegate` keyword and define a concrete delegate type, the compiler generates those methods.
trans-unit.target: When you use the `delegate` keyword and define a concrete delegate type, the compiler generates those methods.

trans-unit.source: In practice, this would lead to creating new delegate types whenever you need a different method signature.
trans-unit.target: In practice, this would lead to creating new delegate types whenever you need a different method signature.

trans-unit.source: This work could get tedious after a time.
trans-unit.target: This work could get tedious after a time.

trans-unit.source: Every new feature requires new delegate types.
trans-unit.target: Every new feature requires new delegate types.

trans-unit.source: Thankfully, this isn't necessary.
trans-unit.target: Thankfully, this isn't necessary.

trans-unit.source: The .NET Core framework contains several types that you can reuse whenever you need delegate types.
trans-unit.target: The .NET Core framework contains several types that you can reuse whenever you need delegate types.

trans-unit.source: These are [generic](generics.md) definitions so you can declare customizations when you need new method declarations.
trans-unit.target: These are [generic](generics.md) definitions so you can declare customizations when you need new method declarations.

trans-unit.source: The first of these types is the @System.Action type, and several variations:
trans-unit.target: The first of these types is the @System.Action type, and several variations:

trans-unit.source: The `in` modifier on the generic type argument is covered in the article on covariance.
trans-unit.target: The `in` modifier on the generic type argument is covered in the article on covariance.

trans-unit.source: There are variations of the `Action` delegate that contain up to 16 arguments such as @System.Action%6016 .
trans-unit.target: There are variations of the `Action` delegate that contain up to 16 arguments such as @System.Action%6016 .

trans-unit.source: It's important that these definitions use different generic arguments for each of the delegate arguments: That gives you maximum flexibility.
trans-unit.target: It's important that these definitions use different generic arguments for each of the delegate arguments: That gives you maximum flexibility.

trans-unit.source: The method arguments need not be, but may be, the same type.
trans-unit.target: The method arguments need not be, but may be, the same type.

trans-unit.source: Use one of the `Action` types for any delegate type that has a void return type.
trans-unit.target: Use one of the `Action` types for any delegate type that has a void return type.

trans-unit.source: The framework also includes several generic delegate types that you can use for delegate types that return values:
trans-unit.target: The framework also includes several generic delegate types that you can use for delegate types that return values:

trans-unit.source: The `out` modifier on the result generic type argument is covered in the article on covariance.
trans-unit.target: The `out` modifier on the result generic type argument is covered in the article on covariance.

trans-unit.source: There are variations of the `Func` delegate with up to 16 input arguments such as @System.Func%6017 .
trans-unit.target: There are variations of the `Func` delegate with up to 16 input arguments such as @System.Func%6017 .

trans-unit.source: The type of the result is always the last type parameter in all the `Func` declarations, by convention.
trans-unit.target: The type of the result is always the last type parameter in all the `Func` declarations, by convention.

trans-unit.source: Use one of the `Func` types for any delegate type that returns a value.
trans-unit.target: Use one of the `Func` types for any delegate type that returns a value.

trans-unit.source: There's also a specialized @System.Predicate%601 type for a delegate that returns a test on a single value:
trans-unit.target: There's also a specialized @System.Predicate%601 type for a delegate that returns a test on a single value:

trans-unit.source: You may notice that for any `Predicate` type, a structurally equivalent `Func` type exists For example:
trans-unit.target: You may notice that for any `Predicate` type, a structurally equivalent `Func` type exists For example:

trans-unit.source: You might think these two types are equivalent.
trans-unit.target: You might think these two types are equivalent.

trans-unit.source: They are not.
trans-unit.target: They are not.

trans-unit.source: These two variables cannot be used interchangeably.
trans-unit.target: These two variables cannot be used interchangeably.

trans-unit.source: A variable of one type cannot be assigned the other type.
trans-unit.target: A variable of one type cannot be assigned the other type.

trans-unit.source: The C# type system uses the names of the defined types, not the structure.
trans-unit.target: The C# type system uses the names of the defined types, not the structure.

trans-unit.source: All these delegate type definitions in the .NET Core Library should mean that you do not need to define a new delegate type for any new feature you create that requires delegates.
trans-unit.target: All these delegate type definitions in the .NET Core Library should mean that you do not need to define a new delegate type for any new feature you create that requires delegates.

trans-unit.source: These generic definitions should provide all the delegate types you need under most situations.
trans-unit.target: These generic definitions should provide all the delegate types you need under most situations.

trans-unit.source: You can simply instantiate one of these types with the required type parameters.
trans-unit.target: You can simply instantiate one of these types with the required type parameters.

trans-unit.source: In the case of algorithms that can be made generic, these delegates can be used as generic types.
trans-unit.target: In the case of algorithms that can be made generic, these delegates can be used as generic types.

trans-unit.source: This should save time, and minimize the number of new types that you need to create in order to work with delegates.
trans-unit.target: This should save time, and minimize the number of new types that you need to create in order to work with delegates.

trans-unit.source: In the next article, you'll see several common patterns for working with delegates in practice.
trans-unit.target: In the next article, you'll see several common patterns for working with delegates in practice.
